title: 113_hr4173
content: The Act is titled the "Brownfield Redevelopment and Economic Development Innovative Financing Act of 2014". It establishes a program for brownfield redevelopment and economic development financing. The Act establishes the Brownfield Redevelopment and Economic Development Innovative Financing program, allowing the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development to guarantee loans for brownfield redevelopment projects. Eligibility requires a master plan and certification from the Environmental Protection Agency. The Brownfield Redevelopment and Economic Development Innovative Financing program requires a master plan and certification from the Environmental Protection Agency for loan eligibility. Loans can be used for various redevelopment costs like site acquisition, remediation, facility relocation, and site preparation. The Brownfield Redevelopment and Economic Development Innovative Financing program requires a master plan and EPA certification for loan eligibility. Loans can be used for site preparation, utilities installation, and transportation facilities. Local agencies cannot receive a loan if responsible for contaminating a brownfield or have more than one outstanding loan. The loan amount must be at least $25,000,000 and not exceed the total cost of the redevelopment project. The loan for brownfield redevelopment projects must be at least $25,000,000 and cannot exceed the total project cost or $150,000,000. The interest rate is negotiated between the lender and borrower, with a repayment term of 20-30 years. Repayment of principal and interest is not required for the first 10 years, with repayment starting within 15 years. A master plan for a brownfield redevelopment project must be submitted within 15 years of the loan being made. The plan should include a project description, budget, and schedule, as well as details on non-Federal funds, job creation, environmental remediation, and community impact. The Secretary shall establish criteria for the selection of brownfield redevelopment projects, including a description of the environmental and economic impact, affordable housing created, reduction of vehicle congestion and emissions, integration of green technology, improvement in air quality, complete streets planning, evidence of non-Federal investment commitments, and an approved remediation action plan. The Secretary will establish selection criteria for local governments and redevelopment projects to receive loan guarantees under the Program, giving favorable consideration to existing projects with Federal assistance. The full faith and credit of the United States is pledged for guarantee payments, and the Federal Government is not liable for environmental remediation. The Federal Government will not be liable for environmental remediation under the loan guarantee program. The Secretary will process requests using a similar approval process as other loan guarantees. Applicants must show a viable repayment schedule and provide sufficient collateral. Before final approval of any loan guarantee under this section, the Secretary must notify relevant Congressional committees. Definitions for the section include "BRAC redevelopment project" as a project to redevelop a site designated as a Base Realignment and Closure Site by the Secretary of Defense.
